scenes.title: Deleting Instagram, gaining time
scenes.main_point: Removing Instagram freed time and attention for intentional reading.
scenes.scene_summary: After deleting Instagram, I found more time, energy, and attention to read intentionally.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
One person at home sets down a phone showing Instagram deleted, then opens a book and begins reading.
Quiet reading moment with a sense of focus and calm.

scenes.title: Curiosity-led reading quota
scenes.main_point: Reading followed curiosity with a simple daily one-hour quota.
scenes.scene_summary: I read whatever sparked curiosity and hit a one-hour daily quota; extra reading felt like bonus.
key_elements: Timer or clock at one hour
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
One person at a desk at home, turning book pages while a timer/clock marks one hour.
Simple daily routine implied; calm, curious focus.

scenes.title: Two books and Feynman’s warning
scenes.main_point: Two books led to Feynman’s principle about self-deception.
scenes.scene_summary: I read Deutsch and Holiday, and both echoed Feynman: don’t fool yourself first.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
A reader sits at a desk with two books visible: The Beginning of Infinity and Ego is the Enemy.
On a nearby screen, Richard Feynman’s quote appears: “The first principle is that you must not fool yourself.”

scenes.title: How high ego blocks learning
scenes.main_point: High ego created stories, blocked beginner mindset, and resisted doing boring practice.
scenes.scene_summary: High ego made me fear sounding bad on guitar and resist learning from a kid.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
In a small practice room, an adult sits with an unplayed guitar, hesitating and making awkward first strums.
Nearby, a child plays the guitar confidently, the adult looking embarrassed and resistant.

scenes.title: Purpose fantasies vs doing what’s needed
scenes.main_point: Chasing grand purpose hid basic neglect; reality required doing immediate, unglamorous work.
scenes.scene_summary: I chased world-changing purpose while neglecting basics; real leaders just did needed tasks.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
One person in a messy room stares at a to-do list of basic habits while holding cleaning supplies beside visible trash.
A bold “world-changing purpose” title scribble contrasts with the unglamorous chores, implying humbled realization.

scenes.title: Bad explanations, humility, and low ego
scenes.main_point: Seeking good explanations and humility prevented self-deception; low ego enabled growth after rejection.
scenes.scene_summary: After hackathon rejection, I learned no-code, improved, placed twice, and valued better explanations.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
One person at a desk with a laptop showing a no-code tool, holding a hackathon rejection message beside it.
On the wall, a simple Galileo/heliocentric doodle and floating question marks; the person looks curious and determined.
